title: Classifications
hypotheses:

          src="images/causality/causal_hypothesis.png"
          alt="Hypothesis"
          caption="The possible causalities of the biomarkers"
          n={1}
        />

title: GlialCells
hypotheses:
It is possible to make a model of MEG signal / features based on tau and
        Aβ that takes into account their interactions with one another and with
        glial cells. As it is possible to predict the AD progression based on
        MEG features it would help understand glial cells role in AD
        progression.

title: HUBS
hypotheses:
The vulnerability of hub regions in AD may be due to their high connectivity, which makes them more susceptible to the spread of pathological proteins and the propagation of neurodegenerative processes.
We could try to find the correlation between the connectivity of the region and the vulnerability to AD.

We could make a model to predict the progression of AD based on the
        previous model of signal but adding the connectivity of the regions.

This finding could explain why previous hypersynchronization phenomena
        were found at several frequency bands.

title: Amyloid Beta (AB)
hypotheses:
Aβ plaques concentration is associated with an increased frequency of
        epileptiform activity in AD patients.

In Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) patients, a higher density of Aβ plaques
        will correlate with a flatter PSD slope, particularly in frontal and
        temporal regions, due to decreased perisomatic GABAergic inhibition and
        increased neuronal hyperactivity in these areas.

Regions with high tau pathology in AD patients will show a steeper PSD
        slope due to tau's impact on excitatory neurons, resulting in reduced
        high-frequency power and an increased relative contribution of
        low-frequency activity.

In brain regions with both Aβ and tau pathology, the effect on PSD slope
        will depend on the relative densities of Aβ versus tau: Aβ-dominant
        regions will have a flatter slope, while tau-dominant regions will
        exhibit a steeper slope.

title: Tau
hypotheses:
Regions with High Tau Burden Show Altered Aperiodic Slopes, Reflecting
        an Imbalance in Excitatory-Inhibitory Activity

title: Hyperexcitability
hypotheses:
Hypersynchrony observed in AD is a direct result of Aβ-induced
        overactivation of excitatory neurons due to disrupted inhibitory
        (GABAergic) control, rather than a compensatory mechanism. Supported by{" "}
        <CitationCard citations={[EITranslationalPerspective]}>
          the loss of GABAergic transmission, could induce hyperactivity,
          increasing the probability of local synchronization of brain
          oscillatory activity
        </CitationCard>

If hypersynchrony is driven by Aβ pathology, then directional
        connectivity from regions with higher Aβ load to regions with lower Aβ
        load should show causal hypersynchrony.

title: Frequencies
hypotheses:
Increased Tau Accumulation Leads to Decreased High-Frequency Power
        (Alpha/Beta) in Excitatory-Dominated Regions

High Tau Levels Correlate with Increased Low-Frequency Power
        (Delta/Theta) as a Result of Compensatory Inhibitory Activity

The Ratio of Low- to High-Frequency Power Increases with Tau Load,
        Indicating Shifts Toward Slower Rhythms in Tau-Rich Regions

title: Periodic
